content: So folks who are wringing their hands over the xz backdoor… What are we going to do differently to stop this in the future?  My guess is we will preach and pontificate but not actually do anything useful…just like we always do!

My hot take on the xz back door: it’s a success for the community.  It took 2 years to sneak it in and it was caught in 1 month before it was in any major distro.  It is really hard to backdoor a distro which is pretty cool.

I read all the #autopwn2own articles so you don’t have to.  Here is the best one.  From what I read it looks like the gateway module held up which means attackers can’t control brakes/steering/etc.  That is a win for the tesla security team.  https://t.co/Z9PtaIhwOM
Google, you gave me a lifetime ban on app development 10 years ago, why are you still giving me service updates?  Just rubbing it in? https://t.co/8jpGQ3IvsA

Just looked at the Blackhat sessions.  Only one talk about car hacking, and its a jailbreak using glitching.  Are researchers not interested in this field or is BH just picky about the talks that are presented?
Everyone sure turned against Twitter encrypted DMs in a hurry!
Over my decades in computer security, I've really matured.  For example, right now I'm redoing my kitchen and didn't even sell a 0-day to the US government to fund it.

Reasons why twitter e2e encryption was rejected in the past 1) can’t https://t.co/aVSAB3FEG0 your links (so lose visibility). 2) can’t scan for spam/abuse/misinformation 3) can’t display “cards” ie layout images nicely 4) can’t standardize photos (ie remove geo info) 5) key mgmt
Interesting read on how you can use CAN injection to steal a car.  This type of attack has been known for many years but nice writeup of how it works in this case.  https://t.co/EwPjo4fIPk
I see a lot of security folks complaining about twitter sms 2fa going away which is weird because I thought they all left for mastadon.

I finally tried out ChatGPT and asked it about my favorite subject, me!  Here are some things it had to say.  Some not so based in facts but I guess the AI knows better than me. https://t.co/6OfORAz6II
@Aaroniscoding Thanks, I hadn’t seen the official write up was out!
Watch for me and others this year doing cyber https://t.co/ciRVVg36yy

Remember when all the twitter employees quit/got fired and they said twitter would break?  I’m not happy with things @elonmusk is doing policy-wise, but at the same time, it is interesting that Twitter still works as well as ever.
Car hacking question to ponder for the weekend.  Why does Tesla make up approximately 80% of all car hacking research while Tesla makes up 2% of US automobiles?

Great telsa hacking research.  https://t.co/KOyxjwJKXP.  Some takeaways from me:  I'm a big fan of CAN gateways, this is another example where that mechanism wasn't bypassed and thus they could not send arbitrary CAN messages.
All the work in my entire life, the entirety of my career, has all led to this moment...  https://t.co/0rQTtr6Zjl
Maybe it’s my imagination but I think I’m getting more ads on here since Elon took over.
An oldie but a goodie.  Code exec on wifi chip then pivot to attack kernel driver of AP to get remote shell on telematics system of tesla: https://t.co/ou0flrlX9U

Hey All.  I'm sorry to say I was supposed to keynote the @owasp Global Appsec SF conference, but now I won't be able to make it.  If you were going to the conference for me, next time you see me at a conference, say hi and I'll buy you a drink.  Sorry! https://t.co/oBARWBvJxl
How did I go through my whole life without knowing this was a thing: https://t.co/IX3cK1BX4p

Podcast featuring @sickcodes talking about John Deere hacking and some upcoming research on a head unit from a 2019 Dodge truck.  I'll be curious to see what they found as well as how different a 2019 Dodge headunit it from the 2014 Jeep one we looked at. https://t.co/nFyczuU2ZH
OH at work: listening to charlie on ryan's podcast and i keep thinking 'oh f**k, what meeting am i on, i can't find the tab' lol then i realize it's podcast

Part of device security is ensuring what is running on the device is genuine/unmodified.  This runs counter to people who want to modify their device.  You see this everywhere from iphones to cars. https://t.co/bRweDhx1lS
From a talk with me and @dinodaizovi from 2012.  Yep, still true. https://t.co/bT3Ygev5CV
Hey @nudehaberdasher, did we meet while we worked as analysts at the NSA or later?  I forget, its all a little foggy.  https://t.co/FctCUiVgmX

NHTSA released "Cybersecurity Best Practices for the Safety of Modern Vehicles" this month, an update to their 2016 document of similar name which I believe was largely produced in response to our Jeep research.  https://t.co/kBYHCxfhj4
I was going through some old emails and came across this old photo that was not altered in any way.  I miss Cyber Fast Track. https://t.co/NaXWh4A5eK

People used to ask me if Steve Jobs knew who I was as the “apple hacker”.  I’d always said no, he’s too busy running Apple.  But now I think he’d definitely have read a NYT article about iphone and would want to know why they had to update it.  https://t.co/9MuPXA6mkM
Wow, what are you people googling? https://t.co/ox1USeHemf
Are v2v /v2x dead?  https://t.co/PlK0qtVq8s
Bye Las Vegas.  It was great catching up with old friends as well as future hacking stars! https://t.co/R9oGg3KjrT
@DavidCasteel70 they’re hard to get, yea i didn’t know they didn’t steal the car
@DavidCasteel70 no doesn’t sound like relay attack to me

Some thoughts as former appsec tech lead at Twitter on https://t.co/Zl0VIllwzS There was always tension between security and user growth. I imagine this issue stemmed from a "people you might know" feature which is great for user growth but hard to do in a privacy preserving way.

I can't believe it's been 15 years since my first @BlackHatEvents talk.  Back then I spoke at that conference 10 times in 10 years.  Here is a video of my first talk; I had hair and introduced myself as Charles, lol.   https://t.co/WTUm7SfQKe
Ok all you haters, its time for my annual Blackhat preview show where I complain about how Blackhat has changed from what it was 10 years ago and I'm a grumpy old man about it.
@Fr333k @nudehaberdasher I’m a fan of @keen_lab’s bmw research.  Also, liked their tesla gateway module bypass.

When was the last time everyone was standing-room-only excited to see a @BlackHatEvents talk like @dakami breaking DNS or @barnaby_jack jackpotting an ATM?  It’s been a minute.  I miss that excitement (and those researchers).
Bad picture but I think i was so shocked.  It says “honk if you love cybersecurity”.  I did not honk. https://t.co/TWgGOaNHZl
As I look at car hacking research in the last 7 years, I'd say the biggest defensive win is vehicles that have a central gateway module that isolates CAN networks from each other.

A bunch of folks at Cruise have worked really hard to secure self driving cars.  Last night @nudehaberdasher and I finally got to ride in one.  An empty car picked us up and drove us around with no one in the front seat.  It was wild! https://t.co/srubHF4tIB

I used to argue with @bradarkin about finding bugs whereas he thought the focus should be on using sandboxes.  After a bit I realized I was wrong and agreed with him.  Now I think maybe we were both wrong…
@msuiche @dinodaizovi also someone thought apple cared enough about end user security to have a team that would call customers to help them https://t.co/5BWgc5c05Z
I hope there is some good car hacking talks at BH/defcon this year.  If you’re on the PC of those cons and want an opinion on if a talk is good/novel, send it my way, I’ll tell you!

Me and @nudehaberdasher are going to be talking about management, financial portfolios, insurance, computers, black leather gloves, research and development (putting in the hours to study the science of what you need), and security! https://t.co/R80iIh2SmW
If you ever want to fake a badge at the Enterprise Center, here is a handy chart.  I’d go with all season all access. https://t.co/kO7VsatwUm
My favorite thing about vulnerability hunting is that it’s so hard but the results are usually so simple.

I have questions about the iPhone "Unknown Accessory Detected" dialogue as a detection mechanism.  1) What is the false positive rate?  It seems HIGH.  2) What is the action you take in response?  Look everywhere for airpods?
@wrylee @jeremiahg @nudehaberdasher “why didn’t it surface it?”.   The questions would be endless
@haroldsmith3rd @matthew_d_green @mattblaze you mean how car apps store credentials?

Time to talk pwn2own for Tesla target (https://t.co/cQrBKrRkFc).  I think this is a really cool contest and I can't wait to see what researchers come up with.  My prediction is the big prize will NOT be won.  To understand that we need a little background 1/n

Interesting article about reversing the EPS (power steering) module in a car.  When we were hacking the Jeep, an update for that module was not available so we couldn't reverse it, otherwise @a_greenberg would have been in even more trouble.  https://t.co/Am1iwKhcVP
A young me on my first national tv interview in 2007 after hacking the iphone 1. https://t.co/cBbeVGV1Om

In the continuing drama of a reporter pointing out a security flaw in a state website, the governor expects the reporter to be prosecuted.  I’m happy to testify if it goes to trial.  https://t.co/nDLvuNXOzf
I guess it’s time to get rid of my battery hacking research stuff… https://t.co/r8yaiB4dL9
@jabreity yea i can’t make any promises what that firmware does anymore
I just watched @dontlookupfilm and the biggest error in it is that in real life, people don’t give a crap if you’re a doctoral candidate ;)
Missouri governor says report stating FBI agreeing post dispatch reporter did not hack a government website might be fake news.  Sounds like he’s on top of things. https://t.co/71WSOP7CWB
8 years ago today, the track suit photo session!  Time flies! https://t.co/Flv2W0FayW
Dearest iOS, please stop uninstalling apps I don’t use “enough”.  Your loyal user and friend, Charlie
@Aaroniscoding only a few minutes of me, but tons of time with @jms_dot_py
@semibogan @NSWAmbulance not an aussie so what “line” are they reclaiming?

Can someone explain the security benefits of the "your trusted image" displayed at some web sign ins?  Don't get me wrong, I love seeing a cute kitten when I sign in, but I don't see how it is protecting me from anything.

There haven’t been many infosec cons the last couple of years due to covid.  There used to be one every weekend.  What the heck were people talking about in all those talks and was it even helping solve the problem of securing stuff?
Elon Musk saying a fleet wide hack of Tesla cars would be "the end of Tesla".  https://t.co/Bd3Pq2iQ94

I’m not hating on conferences and definitely don’t want to start my own, but as an industry, what we’re doing now isn’t working.  So what can we do better and maybe we shouldn’t just keep doing MORE of the same.
Check out my latest apple tv hack!  #0day #fullDisclosure #bugtraq https://t.co/ohpvij8V7P
Look me and @jennafischer are notable although I think she’s a little more notable than me.  #classof95 https://t.co/VjvOlq3nbJ

One of the most satisfying things about working somewhere for a while are conversations that begin “we knew you’d hate this” or “we knew you’d think this is fine”.  It shows you make people think about security and you have a consistent message.
Replay attacks against Honda key fobs: https://t.co/fjCdUptvm7
i’m going to help make sure the new iOS image scanner used for CSAM is okay, but I seem to be having trouble logging into my apple developer account…
@msuiche @ryanaraine but who was holding court at the corner of that bar?
Remembering that time that ⁦@nudehaberdasher⁩ and I caused a news alert.  Ah the memories! https://t.co/DqD1TUF9je

Thanks to everyone who replied to my comment(s) about community/human factors tracks at blackhat and helped educate me.  I was wrong.  I see how things aren’t black and white (even if I want them to be) and fully support these important tracks/work.  I’m sorry.
I took a look at the @BlackHatEvents schedule.  A few talks looked good: hacking a capsule hotel, printer exploits, zero click against Huawei phones, and fault injection on auto systems
a young(er) iphone hacker circa 2007 https://t.co/BZzkhCH1PL
Hello darkness my old friend… https://t.co/2AZ9UW04cB
I bought a new Jeep today and the sales guy was asking if I knew anything about Uconnect and I said “yes, yes I do…”
I read a translation of the China cybersecurity law and have some thoughts as a security researcher.  https://t.co/LbI1iWuC4Q

By my count, I've given 10 talks at Blackhat (plus judged the Pwnies a few times) but I'm still supposed to pay $2k to go?  I should at least get a discount for the years I had a pass but didn't go to any talks! https://t.co/HWhI25Nire
One of my boys saw this online from when I did ninja warrior, pretty cool https://t.co/Uf0ivzGYXq

Interesting paper about adversarial computer vision in self driving cars.  The idea is to use resonance to make sensors designed to keep cameras stable to actually cause blur and this blur makes object detection algorithms fail.  https://t.co/snUfQ5bGQe

Very theoretical paper but still interesting.  It discusses how to disrupt low level CAN traffic from a compromised ECU, previously thought impossible in a remote compromise situation.  Notice they use a Ford and Toyota for their tests, open research ftw https://t.co/yRdHEIpCr9
Interesting talk about whether stunt hacking "works" to affect change.  https://t.co/hITs6K5kJj

Even though everyone, and especially @ryanaraine, hates when I say it, @BlackHatUSA should only contain highly technical talks.  Less-technical talks are what RSA is for.  (Also, there shouldn't be a "business hall" or pay-to-speak slots).  Yes I lose this argument every year.

In the 6 years since the car Jeep hack, there hasn't been a similar attack (no interaction -> arbitrary CAN messages).  There has been some no interaction remote attacks (eg @esizkur against Tesla) and some arbitrary CAN message (eg @keen_lab against Telsa) but no full attacks.
It’s pretty amazing to me that the Jeep hack occurred over 6 years ago.  It doesn’t feel that long ago! https://t.co/YyZTQANia2

This is a pretty interesting paper about attacks against self-driving car sensor systems.  It demonstrates the typical defense to these attacks (multi sensor fusion) doesn't always work.  This is a problem I've been thinking about a lot lately.  https://t.co/11VJBJxqgj
@lenazun @marciahofmann great choice
getting fired up for game 4!!! https://t.co/6jV0DhRmHi

Another interesting paper by @keen_lab about car hacking, this time a Mercedes.  I read the car hacking papers (this one is 86 pages) so you don't have to!  Thoughts in this thread (1/8) https://t.co/vzURu7Hutr

From readers digest "your car’s USB port poses a significant risk because it can be attacked by viruses. Even just listening to music ... could ... infect your car with malware. And ..., plugging [your phone] into the USB then gives the hackers access to your car’s systems"
NOPE
Computer hacking advice from superstar @ThatBigRon, compliments of @nudehaberdasher. https://t.co/gW8NNXy65V
This strikes me as strange because it’s not like the chinese government can’t write their own exploits... https://t.co/ogTACILGbL
Will miss you @dakami.  You were a cool dude.  Personally, I learned a lot about public speaking from you and aspired to give talks like you.

I see people comparing what the UMN people did to me publishing the app with the code signing exploit in it in the App Store. Its a good comparison except don't forget that I got banned and I accepted my ban with no complaints.  Play in mud, you get dirty  https://t.co/WjWQmQHi5p

The weirdest part of moving from being a car hacker to working for an autonomous car company is seeing how much better the automotive techs are at disassembling cars than I was.  They don't let me near them with tools, which is smart.
Listened to a couple of my favorite people on this podcast today.  As a bonus, they mention me and @nudehaberdasher - https://t.co/vp3VXxKR2F
I was listening to @ryanaraine podcast: security conversations and I think he could be a CISO.

When did pwn2own rules change to “the vendor can’t know about it”?  When I was participating, there were some crazy rules, but when I got a shell, I knew I won.  It didn’t matter what the vendor knew.  In fact, I think they knew about one of my bugs and I still got paid...

This is a weird take on autonomous vehicle security.  They talk about jamming sensors and confusing AI but mostly ignore attackers taking control of a car like we did with the Jeep, which seems to me a way more dangerous and likely as an attack vector. https://t.co/ql86z3nGLJ
@Alex_Ri_000 i agree scalability is a big factor why traditional cyber security attacks are scarier than sensor attacks

I guess Tesla's are officially secure!
https://t.co/U17zgfHjLu
@haroldsmith3rd it’s a little different since they let the genie out of the bottle on that one
